basically it's an observability framework and an open standard that you can use to instrument and collect data
in your environment specifically this is telemetry data traces metrics and logs
being the most common but they are not the only things this open specification is really the foundation of everything
within open Symmetry and what makes it compatible with a variety of different formats that are out there today it's
also what allows the project to be vendor agnostic if you follow this open standard then it shouldn't matter which
back end you're sending the data to as long as it supports open symmetry you should be able to move between different backends however you see fit now that
specification is foundational but on top of it there are basically two reference implementations there are
instrumentation libraries this is what goes in your code in order to generate or instrument the traces metrics logs or
other signals that you care about and then there's a data collection aspect think of it like an agent or like a
Gateway or an aggregator or something to that effect it is used to receive process and Export this Telemetry data
at the end of the day those are the two primary components that you'll see uh we're going to drill into this a little
bit more in just a second now why does open symmetry matter I kind of mentioned it's an open standard and it's vendor
agnostic that's a huge value proposition position for end users because at the end of the day you don't want to use a
vendor solution spend all this investment in it and then if you want to change you have to rip it out and install something else that's very
impactful there's not a lot of value to that and some of these signals like traces for example they have to be
instrumented end end in order to actually see things and be able to troubleshoot so ripping it out is very
costly because you're going to lose observability in your systems for a period of time uh Beyond this you kind
of get data control and portability now you have one standard and one way to actually instrument and collect data in
your environment you control what you send and where you send it to if you want to send it to multiple destinations
that's fine if you want to remove information before you send it that's fine if you want to add information before you send it that's fine uh open
simetry is actually the second most active project in the entire cncf behind

httpstatuscode equals 200 well I want that key name to be uh uniquely
